posts.title: All Black! Be quiet! PURE BASE 500 Build
posts.text: Translated from https://www.chiphell.com/thread-2192145-1-1.html.Only for learning. Translating things is hard af. But it’s fun, right?PS. I’d also like to build something like this, I really love this style! ForewordI didn’t waste time though I was resting at home. So I helped build a system. After trying out builds with all kinds of lighting effects, a system with out lighting effects seems to be more out-standing. I used Ryzen 7 3700X + X570 + RTX 2080 platform. Considering that it has no lighting effects, I chose be quiet!‘s PURE BASE 500 for the case. It has a simple but elegant design and is pretty easy to install. For cooling, an air-cooling solution with out RGB was the best choice. It turned out to be extreamly quiet. And as for the power-supply, I used a HCG750 with 10 years waranty. Here are the basic requirements for this build: Powerful and can handle jobs for designing, video and photo editing and can provide a smooth experience playing PUBG or watching hi-res videos. Look simple and does need to have any lighting effects. Have good expandability and is easy to add additional memory and storage later. Build specs: Processor AMD Ryzen 7 3700X Motherboard Asus STRIX X570-E GAMING Memory Corsair dominator platinum DDR4 3200 16GB x 2 Graphics Card EVGA GeForce RTX 2080 FTW3 ULTRA GAMING SSD Storage Wd SN750 1TB Cooler be quiet! DARK ROCK PRO 4 Cooling Fan be quiet! SILENT WINGS 3 PWM 120mm x 4 Power-supply Antec HCG750 Gold Case be quiet! PURE BASE 500 (with glass panel) Build Show45° The front view of the case: it uses a round-cut design and has a quality brushed finish be quiet!‘s logo Front IO and button: 2 USB 3.0, start button and audio jack. Top View of the case: A dust filter and cooling holes at the back of the case. After removing the panel, you can see the top mounting holes for the fans. It also includes a magnetic dust filter which can stick to the top of the case to help improve cooling. The back of the case: A large filter at the bottom of the case: Can be pulled out for cleaning. On the left side of the case, there is a large piece of tempered glass. And on the right is steel.After removing the panel: 45° Main components. You can see it’s almost matt black and grey. The HUGE cooler: Memory: A little cover for cable management. It has a be quiet! logo on it. Graphics card:The 3 slot card is really bulky. You can see the THICK heat sink and heat pipe. RTX 2080: Jumpers on the mother board: There is plenty of holes at the top of the power-supply to provide cool air for the graphics card. Three 12cm fans in the front of the case to intake fresh air: The jumper cover where you can hide your pci-e power cord. The cool air will be directly sent to the CPU cooler, and then exhausted by the fan on the back. You cannot install the graphics card vertically. Mounting holes on the back of the mother board: support dual 2.5 inch hard drive. Cables: Power-supply base: Front hard drive base: you can install two 3.5 inch hard drive Components and hardwareAsus STRIX X570-E GAMING A protection shield with RGB. Cooler for the south-bridge chipset. (I think it’s south-bridge) Memory slots Rear-IO: It has basicly everything you need. AMD Ryzen 7 3700x Corsair dominator platinum DDR4 3200 16GB x 2, feel decent, it’s a good choice. After installing: Installing SN750 1TB: EVGA GeForce RTX 2080 FTW3 ULTRA GAMING, a 3-slot graphics card, looks very bulky. R!G!B! lights (It’s not All Black now) 8pin + 8pin power plug. Cooling fans: Metal backplate with cooling holes in it: Graphics IO: You can see those thick heat-pipes on the left side of the graphics card. be quiet! DARK ROCK PRO 4, a gigantic dual-tower cooler which is completely in black. be quiet! SILENT WINGS 3 PWM 120mm fan (high speed ver.) Antec’s HCG750 Gold power-supply with 10 year waranty is a decent choice. Installing The cpu cooler perfectly avoid crushing the memory slots when only 2 of the 4 RAMs are installed. After installing the graphics card. (Wait, you haven’t plug in your cables yet!) That’s it, I cut off the case part because I think it’s a little bit unnecessary. You can see it in the original post. ( I am too lazy to translate it :P ) The final post will be about performance stuff. Performance testAI Suite 3 Manually overclock to 4.3GHz. EVGA Precision can be used for monitoring, overclocking and configuring lighting effects. CPU-Zscreenshot. CPU-Z benchmark. GPU-Z screenshots, luckly, it uses Samsung memory chips. FTW3 can show many different temperatures. Screenshot of Thaiphoon Burner. CINEBENCH R20.0 result, CPU score is 5207 points. CINEBENCH R15.0 results, OpenGL score is 144.63 fps and CPU score is 2286 cb. AIDA64 memory test. SSD performance test. 3DMark Fire Strike gets a score of 24939 and 29175. 3DMark Fire Strike Extreme gets a score of 13781 and 14242. 3DMark Fire Strike Ultra gets a score of 7224 and 7019. 3DMark Time Spy gets a score of 11835 and 12068. 3DMark Time Spy Extreme gets a score of 5397 and 5504. 3DMark Royal Port gets a score of 7046. Manually overclocked to 4.3GHz (full core).Then run a benchmark using AIDA64 FPU for 10 minutes, the average CPU core temperature was 63.2 ℃. https://static.chiphell.com/forum/202003/03/214116wkxzfplze7ppsggx.png Use Furmark to run the graphics card benchmark. After running for 10 minutes under full load, the temperature is around 71 ℃. That’s it. I’ve finally finished translating this…it’s also my first attempt to translate things. So hope I haven’t made too much mistakes. :D
